ERRY,AT
VOL. XXIII, NO. 9.

IN GERMAN PRISON CAMP
Captain Maxson Tells of Experiences as
Captive—Treated Well When Germans Saw They Were Defeated.

Captain C. W. Maxson, U. S. A.,
who had been captured three
times by the Germans, had escaped
twice, but on his third capture
had been retained for eight
months a prisoner in Camp Rastaat, Baden, spoke at the mass
meeting on April 3.
"The psychology of the Germans is hard to understand; he
is better to deal with when he is
losing than when he is winning,"
said the speaker. Captain Maxson
was unfortunately a prisoner of
War when Germany was winning.
Ile said the German, when winning, was arrogant, proud, unbearable in his manner. The reverse was true when in 1918 the
fortunes of war turned and the
allied offensive began. The Germans probably foresaw the inevitable and tried to please Americans after the 15 of July. From
that time on every courtesy was
shown to American prisoners.
Captain Maxson told an interesting anecdote of the battle
around Amiens in which he was
captured, when the American
army demonstrated for the first
time its ability and bravery. His
sector had been retreating on a
fifty-mile front; they had fallen
back for a depth of thirty miles.
On the third day the first-organized body of troops he had seen
for days passed him, counterattacking against the vastly superior German strength. It was
Company B and Company C of
the Sixth American Engineers.
Those very boys were the ones
who went into battle at the critical moment and saved Amiens,
pivot point of allied communications. They went in to do or die;
28 per cent. died, the remaining
72 per cent. did. They felt that
as they fought, so America would
be judged as a fighting force by
ally and enemy.
The speaker saw no atrocities
during his imprisonment except
that• the English and French privates, who were never sent back
to Germany but who were kept
in the occupied French territory,
were in a most pitiable condition.
They were examples of no open
abuse, but of neglect. They had
no way of communicating with
home, they worked from sun-up
to • sun-down on a scant diet of
black bread and acorn coffee, and
on rare occasions some soup in
which horse meat was sometimes
present. He reiterated that he
saw no open atrocities but he did

BALTIMORE, MD., APRIL 8, 1919.

COL. MORROW INSPECTS R.O.T.C. 'VARSITY TRIMS FORMER STARS

PRICE, FIVE CENTS

DR. BRUSH SAYS FAREWELL

Chairman of Committee on Education
and Special Training and Other
Officers Study Work of Unit—
Another Officer for Hopkins.

Captain Baxley, Silberstein, and Sutton
Form Strong Attack Combination—
Morley and Dougherty Play
Good Defensive Game.

Presented with Gifts from Undergraduates and Student Council on Leaving
—Invites Students to Visit
Him at Tome.

The entire battalion turned out
on Thursday, April 3, on the occasion of a visit of inspection by
a number of officers from the
War Department. As was made
known sometime ago, so favorable
a report was made concerning
the work of the Hopkins R. 0.
T. C. unit by the District Inspector, that Col. F. J. Morrow, chairman of the Committee on Education and Special Training, of the
War Department, expressed the
desire to inspect the unit in
person.
Accordingly, Col. Morrow was
the inspecting officer Thursday.
afternoon. With him were Lt.Col. L. W. Redington, Lt.-Col. D.
F. E.'Casteel, Maj. 0. C. Drew
and Maj. R. B. Perry, secretary
of the committee. These officers
made a thorough study of the
work of the Hopkins unit, of the
equipment used in the various
classes of Military Science, of the
courses offered, and of the methods used in instruction.
After 'the battalion formation
on the upper quadrangle, the men
were marched by classes to their
lecture rooms. The seniors were
engaged in army paper-work the
junior and sophomore classes
went to their engineering models
and the freshmen company gave
an exhibition drill. The time of
the visitors was divided among
these activities, all of which
seemed to arouse great interest.
The whole unit, it may be said,
made a very creditable showing.
It is understood that the fact
alone of such a visit can be accepted with a great deal of satisfaction by those interested in the
success of the Hopkins battalion.
A personal visit by the head of
the committee in charge of the
reserve officers' training corps
units reflects credit on the efforts
of Captain Guild, and on the
spirit of the members of the battalion.
Announcement was made last
week by Captain Guild that the
services of another officer had
been secured for the Hopkins
unit. James S. Candee, first lieutenant, infantry, has just been
assigned to this institution, and
will make a valuable addition to
the personnel of the instructors.
It is not known at present when
Lieutenant Candee will report.

The 'Varsity lacrosse team
opened its season auspiciously
last Saturday afternoon by defeating the Alumni-4 to 1. The
game was a battle from start to
finish, and only the splendid
work of the 'Varsity's close defense prevented the rain of shots
of the Alumni attack from counting. No credit should be taken
from the playing of the 'Varsity
attack, headed by Eggie Sutton
Silberstein, which
and Sam
showed splendid team-work and
individual ability for the opening
game.
It is generally said that the
Alumni are too old and shortwinded to stand the strain of the
second half. Such was not the
case Saturday, for the veterans
played steadily all through the
game, and scored their lone tally
in the last ten minutes of play,
fighting the 'Varsity to a standstill in the second period.
Before the opening of the game
a touch of solemnity was added
when "Father Bill" Schmeisser
presented to Captain Baxley, in
behalf of the Alumni lacrosse
men, a small silk memorial
*flag in honor of those former
lacrosse players who laid down
their lives in the war. The three
names inscribed on the flag were
those of Lieutenants W. Brown
Baxley, Warren M. Bunting and
Theodore Prince. As stated in
the resolution offered with the
presentation, it is the purpose of
the memorial to emphasize the
wonderful spirit of these men,
and to perpetuate the memory of
their sacrifice in the name of
their university and of their
country. The flag is to be pinned
on the goal net during coming
contests to remind the players
that these men are always in the
fight, though not in body, and it
is to be presented to each successive captain at each annual
lacrosse banquet.
First blood was drawn by Captain Baxley after five minutes of
play, following a beautiful pass
from „Silberstein. The 'Varsity
again came within scoring distance but failed, and for the next
few minutes the ball was held at
the •'Varsity goal with Johnny
Knipp, Boyce and Armstrong
driving in tihot after shot, all of
which Dougherty successfully
warded off, ably assisted by the
brilliant work of Morley at point.
Three more goals were scored
before the half ended, by Sutton,

Words of farewell were exchanged between the Johns Hopkins student body and the retiring
dean, Dr. Brush, at a mass-meeting held on Thursday, April 3.
Vertrees Wyckoff presided and introduced the speakers. Harris
Kirk, as president of the Student
Council, made the presentation
and farewell speech to Dr. Brush.
He gracefully pronounced the sincere feelings of the college in his
words of tribute to Dr. Brush,
touching on the appreciation for
his kindness and services and the
regret at his departure. At the
close of his remarks, he presented
Dr. Brush with two gifts from the
undergraduates—a leather portfolio, which he remarked might be
of some practical use, and a handsomely engraved scroll, a tribute
prepared by the Student Council.
Dr. Brush, in reply, expressed
his thanks for the gifts. A laugh
greeted him when he spoke of a
former gift from a Hopkins graduating class, which had taken the
form of a silver hairbrush. The
retiring dean told the students
that they had co-operated well
with the administration of the college, performing their task honorably, loyally and without prodding. He regretted that he was
leaving Hopkins for a new field
of work, but said that he liked his
new "job" and he cordially invited the college to visit him at
Tome.
Baxley and Williams, making the
score 4 to 0 at the close of the
period.
The second half brought out
better play on both sides, the ball
see-sawing from one end of the
field to the other with no score.
Finally, Bill Swartz, who substituted for Armstrong, managed to
slip one past Dougherty for the
single count of the older men.
Several times the Alumni threatened to score, but were unable.
Honors were about even in this
half, and the Alumni were unable
to make up the advantage which
the 'Varsity gained in the first
half.
The 'Varsity team showed up
very well, and special credit
should be given to the defensive
work of Morley and Dougherty.
Sutton, Silberstein and Captain
Baxley look like a mighty •good
scoring combination and should
make a lot of trouble for opposing teams this year.

TELLS OF SHIP CONSTRUCTION
Aldred Lecturer Describes Modern Steel
Freight Ships Designed for TransAtlantic Trade—Discussses Cost
of Building and Operating.

"The Modern Steel Freight
Ship" was the subject of the
Aldred lecture of April 2 delivered by Mr. D. D. Thomas, chief
engineer of the Baltimore Dry
Docks and Shipbuilding Company.
The size of the ships now being
built for the trans-Atlantic trade,
Mr. Thomas stated, is a matter
of wide discussion, as well as of
great disagreement. Full information must be given the builder
by the owners, regarding the uses
for which the vessels are intended. Consideration must be
given to the types of cargohandling machinery, and likewise
to the running apparatus. The
boilers, engines, and their auxiliaries must be designed to meet
operating conditions. Where oil
is obtainable for fuel, water-tube
boilers are best for coal, Scotch
boilers are most widely used.
The cost of building and operating ships depends upon the materials and speed of construction,
upon the fuel used in running,
the wages of the crew, and the
economy of operation and possibilities of reduction of the engineroom force. Large ships cost less
in proportion than smaller ones,
but their size is limited by the
ports and by weather conditions
at sea. In the future most of the
freight ships will be over 1,800
tons dead weight capacity.
The construction of one of the
new fabricated steel ships was
next outlined. After the specifications have been drawn up, and
the contract has been given, the
mid-ship section and profile plans
are made, using data from previous ships. The distribution of
weights is effected by dividing
the ship into "weight groups."
The lines are then designed. Detail plans are made in the drafting room in their logical order
as needed. A model is made from
the lines determined, to a small
scale, and the plates are laid out
on its surfaces. The task of laying out the full-size molds and
;templates is then accomplished in
the mold loft, by a system of perpendicular offsets. It must be remembered that certain parts of
the ships have many intricate
systems of curvature, and much
care must be taken if all of the
sections are to fit together neatly.
The fabrication consists of preparing the members for assembly.
Identification of all of the parts
is an important detail. The process of fabrication has advanced
so much in the last few years
that now 80 per cent. of the material of the ship may be prepared
away from the ship, speeding up
the work immeasurably.

MANUFACTURERS OF

HIGH GRADE CHOCOLATES.

The subject for the 1919 contest
for the medal offered by the Baron
Coubertin for the best oral discussion of modern French politics
or literature will be: "The Future of France as Influenced by
a League of Nations."
Suggested sub-topics:
(a) The future of France in a
Europe of alliances and balances
of Power.
(b) The burden of reconstruction and the national defense.
(c) France and sea power.
(d) What France deserves from
her allies.
Preliminary trials to select
three or four speakers will be held
April 9, at 1 o'clock, in Room 112.
Speeches of four minutes will be
adequate. The final contest will
probably be held May 9. In that
contest the speeches will be ten
minutes in length.
The Tocqueville contest is open
to all undergraduates, and it is
to be hoped that a large number
of men will try out. It is the
most significant prize that a collegiate student can win.

BALTIMORE, MD.,

APRIL 8, 1919

The Opening Game.

Since the Alumni boasted practically, the same galaxy of stars
as the year previous, the 'Varsity
victory has a most welcome significance. We may look next Saturday for complete revenge for
the 12 to 0 defeat handed us
by Navy last April. It is to
be regretted that Saturday's
weather spoiled the baseball
team's chances for such vengeance, but that score can be settled a few weeks hence.
We might have expected that
such an auspicious opening of
the season at Homewood would
have infused irrepressible pep
into the stands. The yells, however, were of the very poorest
order; not only were they lacking in technique, but in volume
and enthusiasm. Practice can
and must be held, preferably at
a mass meeting, or after some of
the weekly lectures. The yells
should, by all means, have been
rehearsed at the fully-attended
meeting last Thursday in the C.
E. hall, just two days before the
Alumni game.
A feature of the game which
well deserves notice was the presence at one of the goals of a service flag with three gold stars.
The Lacrosse Association has
drawn up a set of resolutions
providing for a service flag with
stars in honor of the memory of
three former Hopkins lacrosse
players who made the supreme
sacrifice.
This simple memorial on the
field on which these three brave
spirits gave their best for Hopkins, is especially appropriate.

Saturday, when youth and endurance reinstated a long-standing

RHODES SCHOLARSHIPS RESUMED
Former Qualifying Examination to Be
Discontinued—Candidates Need Only
Make Formal Application, Endorsed by the Authorities

As recently announced, appointments to Rhodes scholarships in
the United States, which were
postponed for the duration of the
war, will be resumed in October,
1919. The scholarships which
were not awarded during the war
will be allotted in addition to the
current ones during the next three
years.
In his will, Cecil Rhodes provided that two scholarships be constantly at Oxford from each State
in the Union. During the three
years of the Oxford course, the
scholar stays at Oxford and receives the sum of three hundred
pounds a year, out of which he
pays his tuition, fees and expenses,
exactly as . any other student.
There are no restrictions as to
the subjects which he is to study.
Rhodes scholars may choose any
of the various Oxford Honor
Schools, or may work for the Oxford research degrees. Candidates
must be unmarried, between the
ages of nineteen and twenty-five
and must have completed at least
their second year in college. Candidates may try for the appointment either from the State 'in
which they reside or from that
in which. they have received the
major part of their education.
The qualifying examination
which has been required of all
candidates in the past is now to
be abandoned, and to try for the
appointment it will only be necessary for candidates to make formal application, endorsed by the

character, (3) interest in outdoor
sports, and (4) interest in one's
fellows and instincts for leadership.

be made by committees constituted for that purpose in each State.

whom application should be made
and the formal application blanks
will be published in June.

IN GERMAN PRISON CAMP
(Continued from fiage 1)
IS

see boys brought to the hospitals
in so exhausted a condition that
they expired soon after they were
brought in. Captain Maxson experienced no brutality. He was
soon sent back to the prison camp
and always treated as an American officer. The American Red
Cross and the Y. M. C. A. performed wonderful service at the
German prison camps, where university extension work was carried on. Captain Maxson paid a
great tribute to the American
privates. "The American private
in Germany was the finest soldier I have ever seen," he said.
"He so conducted himself that he
won the respect of his enemies

at once."
The German student-body from
the German universities were at
all times out of harmony with
Germany. They saw nothing but
disaster whether win or lose. The
one-time prisoner saw a demonstration of the German revolution. He said the future of Germany looked very uncertain. She
has the spirit to win, but whether
she will or not depends on
whether she will be .able to overcome the Bolshevik tendency.
Captain Maxson hopes that the
college men of America will help
to keep American spirit on as
firm a basis of true social democracy as it was in 1913, through
the period of discontent now facing the world. America has
shown the world that her past is
a guarantee of the future. Un-

less we refuse to permit the
Bolshevik tendencies, our future,
he says, will be as black as Germany's.

Get-together Meetings for Student Body.
To the Eaitor of THE NEWS-LETTER:

Sir:—The Johns Hopkins University is so well known that an
outsider naturally expects to find
Within the student body a spirit
of University pride and unity
equal to the reputation. This
Spirit is noticeable for its absence rather than for its presence. Entering Hopkins from a
less well known college, I have
been greatly disappointed, not in
the faculty or grade of scholarship, but in the lack of organization in the undergraduate body.
One can scarcely realize that
there is no time at which all the
classes come together for an address by the president, dean, or
faculty of the University. A
general announcement cannot be
made, nor can an important matter be urged except through_ a
specially printed card, the MowsLETTER, or the use of the Open
Forum on Thursday through the
courtesy of the Y. M. C. A. cabinet. The greatest spirit, enthusiasm, and feeling of unity is
found where get-together meetings are held, whether at the
training table, smokers in the
dorms, discussion groups, or in
the fraternities. Such a meeting
in this University body would be
no exception.
Through the chapel the majority of the colleges in this country
meet this need. Such a meeting
Of students for a short time offers a chance for a talk by the
officers of the University as well
as student announcements of all
activities. The new athletic program can get its strength from
this source, the Hopkins spirit its
life.
0. W. U.

subscribe to the Hullabaloo is
their duty both to the University
and themselves that I am writing
this letter.
It should be emphasized that
this year's Uullabaloo, as never
before, will represent every class
equally. Every student activity
from freshman to senior will receive equal attention. Furthermore this year's staff is no longer
hampered by war conditions, and
every effort will be made to make
this book a worthy memorial to
the great work which Hopkins
has done in the past war. That
this effort will be a success is
undoubted. More and better material, more pictures and better
drawings have been received than
ever before. Even without further additions this year's Hullabaloo would be the best ever published, and with every additional
dollar more can be added to it.
It is needless I think to point
out that, in addition to these
facts, it is through the Hullabaloo
only that we can obtain a perfect
and lasting record of the activities of our class during its freshman year.
A FRESHMAN.

PHI BETA KAPPAS TO BE
ELECTED APRIL 15th.

The annual meeting of the PhiBeta Kappa Society will be held
on Tuesday, April 15. At this
meeting a lucky half-dozen members of the Class of 1919 will be
elected to the society on the basis
of their scholarship during the
past four years. For the next few
months wrist watches will be discarded, so that the keys may
adorn the watch chain on the
vest. The banquet will be held
on Saturday night, April 26, and
although the arrangements have
not been completed, it is known
that Dr. Joseph Ames will be one
of the speakers.

The two lower classes are working hard in preparation for the
annual freshman-sophomore track
meet, which is scheduled for Friday, April 11, at 3:30 p. m.
While the sophs have slightly the
edge on the freshmen in the actual ability of several of their
runners, the spirit of the freshmen is decidedly the better, and
that, coupled with *Some over-confidence on the part of the sophs,

and Norwood are going to put up

Senior Banquet Rich in Song, Dance,
and Jest--President Goodnow and
Dr. Hulburt Unable to Attend
—"Tiff's" Wit in Evid ence.

A group of forty-seven seniors
gathered at the Hotel Emerson
on March 31, and, figuratively
speaking, took the roof off the
house; for this was the prerogative of the senior banquet. After
keeping the class waiting for
about an hour—perhaps for the
purpose of putting all edge on the
appetites — the committee announced dinner.
Mr. Williams, commonly known
as "Tiff," was the toastmaster,
and his scintillating wit was
evinced in the veritable barrage
of stories which he "got away
with." He first introduced President Chisholm, who spoke about
"The Class." A note of sadness
was drawn into this speech when
President Chisholm remarked that
this would probably be the last
time the class would meet "on
common ground." The gloom, however, speedily disappeared after
Mr. Schmidt's opening sentence,
for he refused "to get off any serious stuff." He launched a witty
tirade against the academic men,
large numbers of whom seem to
have gotten an average of ten or
close to it. Mr. Schmidt attributes this to the fact that the academic courses are easier than
those given in the Engineering Department.
At this point, the toastmaster
announced that President Goodnow, who was to have been the
guest of honor, was prevented
from attending the banquet by illhealth, and he had requested the
toastmaster to convey his regrets
to the class. Mr. Harris Kirk
then spoke on "Reminiscences of
Our Freshman Banquet," and told
of the halcyon days when sophomores were served with the food
for the amusement of the "freshies." "Tommy" was scheduled to
speak on "The Hullabaloo," but
as he is the editor of that book,
and felt that he could not with
delicacy give it its due measure
of praise, he told some side-splitting—that's what he termed them
—negro stories instead. But the
hit of the evening was made by
heavy John Stanley, who chanted
a piece entitled "Damn 9111Pir
Eyes," which brought sponta

IN GERMAN PRISON CAMP
Captain Maxson Tells of Experiences as
Captive—Treated Well When Germans Saw They Were Defeated.

Captain C. W. Maxson, U. S. A.,
who had been captured three
times by the Germans, had escaped
twice, but on his third capture
had been retained for eight
months a prisoner in Camp Rastaat, Baden, spoke at the mass
meeting on April 3.
"The psychology of the Germans is hard to understand; he
is better to deal with when he is
losing than when he is winning,"
said the speaker. Captain Maxson
was unfortunately a prisoner of
War when Germany was winning.
Ile said the German, when winning, was arrogant, proud, unbearable in his manner. The reverse was true when in 1918 the
fortunes of war turned and the
allied offensive began. The Germans probably foresaw the inevitable and tried to please Americans after the 15 of July. From
that time on every courtesy was
shown to American prisoners.
Captain Maxson told an interesting anecdote of the battle
around Amiens in which he was
captured, when the American
army demonstrated for the first
time its ability and bravery. His
sector had been retreating on a
fifty-mile front; they had fallen
back for a depth of thirty miles.
On the third day the first-organized body of troops he had seen
for days passed him, counterattacking against the vastly superior German strength. It was
Company B and Company C of
the Sixth American Engineers.
Those very boys were the ones
who went into battle at the critical moment and saved Amiens,
pivot point of allied communications. They went in to do or die;
28 per cent. died, the remaining
72 per cent. did. They felt that
as they fought, so America would
be judged as a fighting force by
ally and enemy.
The speaker saw no atrocities
during his imprisonment except
that• the English and French privates, who were never sent back
to Germany but who were kept
in the occupied French territory,
were in a most pitiable condition.
They were examples of no open
abuse, but of neglect. They had
no way of communicating with
home, they worked from sun-up
to • sun-down on a scant diet of
black bread and acorn coffee, and
on rare occasions some soup in
which horse meat was sometimes
present. He reiterated that he
saw no open atrocities but he did

BALTIMORE, MD., APRIL 8, 1919.

COL. MORROW INSPECTS R.O.T.C. 'VARSITY TRIMS FORMER STARS

PRICE, FIVE CENTS

DR. BRUSH SAYS FAREWELL

Chairman of Committee on Education
and Special Training and Other
Officers Study Work of Unit—
Another Officer for Hopkins.

Captain Baxley, Silberstein, and Sutton
Form Strong Attack Combination—
Morley and Dougherty Play
Good Defensive Game.

Presented with Gifts from Undergraduates and Student Council on Leaving
—Invites Students to Visit
Him at Tome.

The entire battalion turned out
on Thursday, April 3, on the occasion of a visit of inspection by
a number of officers from the
War Department. As was made
known sometime ago, so favorable
a report was made concerning
the work of the Hopkins R. 0.
T. C. unit by the District Inspector, that Col. F. J. Morrow, chairman of the Committee on Education and Special Training, of the
War Department, expressed the
desire to inspect the unit in
person.
Accordingly, Col. Morrow was
the inspecting officer Thursday.
afternoon. With him were Lt.Col. L. W. Redington, Lt.-Col. D.
F. E.'Casteel, Maj. 0. C. Drew
and Maj. R. B. Perry, secretary
of the committee. These officers
made a thorough study of the
work of the Hopkins unit, of the
equipment used in the various
classes of Military Science, of the
courses offered, and of the methods used in instruction.
After 'the battalion formation
on the upper quadrangle, the men
were marched by classes to their
lecture rooms. The seniors were
engaged in army paper-work the
junior and sophomore classes
went to their engineering models
and the freshmen company gave
an exhibition drill. The time of
the visitors was divided among
these activities, all of which
seemed to arouse great interest.
The whole unit, it may be said,
made a very creditable showing.
It is understood that the fact
alone of such a visit can be accepted with a great deal of satisfaction by those interested in the
success of the Hopkins battalion.
A personal visit by the head of
the committee in charge of the
reserve officers' training corps
units reflects credit on the efforts
of Captain Guild, and on the
spirit of the members of the battalion.
Announcement was made last
week by Captain Guild that the
services of another officer had
been secured for the Hopkins
unit. James S. Candee, first lieutenant, infantry, has just been
assigned to this institution, and
will make a valuable addition to
the personnel of the instructors.
It is not known at present when
Lieutenant Candee will report.

The 'Varsity lacrosse team
opened its season auspiciously
last Saturday afternoon by defeating the Alumni-4 to 1. The
game was a battle from start to
finish, and only the splendid
work of the 'Varsity's close defense prevented the rain of shots
of the Alumni attack from counting. No credit should be taken
from the playing of the 'Varsity
attack, headed by Eggie Sutton
Silberstein, which
and Sam
showed splendid team-work and
individual ability for the opening
game.
It is generally said that the
Alumni are too old and shortwinded to stand the strain of the
second half. Such was not the
case Saturday, for the veterans
played steadily all through the
game, and scored their lone tally
in the last ten minutes of play,
fighting the 'Varsity to a standstill in the second period.
Before the opening of the game
a touch of solemnity was added
when "Father Bill" Schmeisser
presented to Captain Baxley, in
behalf of the Alumni lacrosse
men, a small silk memorial
*flag in honor of those former
lacrosse players who laid down
their lives in the war. The three
names inscribed on the flag were
those of Lieutenants W. Brown
Baxley, Warren M. Bunting and
Theodore Prince. As stated in
the resolution offered with the
presentation, it is the purpose of
the memorial to emphasize the
wonderful spirit of these men,
and to perpetuate the memory of
their sacrifice in the name of
their university and of their
country. The flag is to be pinned
on the goal net during coming
contests to remind the players
that these men are always in the
fight, though not in body, and it
is to be presented to each successive captain at each annual
lacrosse banquet.
First blood was drawn by Captain Baxley after five minutes of
play, following a beautiful pass
from „Silberstein. The 'Varsity
again came within scoring distance but failed, and for the next
few minutes the ball was held at
the •'Varsity goal with Johnny
Knipp, Boyce and Armstrong
driving in tihot after shot, all of
which Dougherty successfully
warded off, ably assisted by the
brilliant work of Morley at point.
Three more goals were scored
before the half ended, by Sutton,

Words of farewell were exchanged between the Johns Hopkins student body and the retiring
dean, Dr. Brush, at a mass-meeting held on Thursday, April 3.
Vertrees Wyckoff presided and introduced the speakers. Harris
Kirk, as president of the Student
Council, made the presentation
and farewell speech to Dr. Brush.
He gracefully pronounced the sincere feelings of the college in his
words of tribute to Dr. Brush,
touching on the appreciation for
his kindness and services and the
regret at his departure. At the
close of his remarks, he presented
Dr. Brush with two gifts from the
undergraduates—a leather portfolio, which he remarked might be
of some practical use, and a handsomely engraved scroll, a tribute
prepared by the Student Council.
Dr. Brush, in reply, expressed
his thanks for the gifts. A laugh
greeted him when he spoke of a
former gift from a Hopkins graduating class, which had taken the
form of a silver hairbrush. The
retiring dean told the students
that they had co-operated well
with the administration of the college, performing their task honorably, loyally and without prodding. He regretted that he was
leaving Hopkins for a new field
of work, but said that he liked his
new "job" and he cordially invited the college to visit him at
Tome.
Baxley and Williams, making the
score 4 to 0 at the close of the
period.
The second half brought out
better play on both sides, the ball
see-sawing from one end of the
field to the other with no score.
Finally, Bill Swartz, who substituted for Armstrong, managed to
slip one past Dougherty for the
single count of the older men.
Several times the Alumni threatened to score, but were unable.
Honors were about even in this
half, and the Alumni were unable
to make up the advantage which
the 'Varsity gained in the first
half.
The 'Varsity team showed up
very well, and special credit
should be given to the defensive
work of Morley and Dougherty.
Sutton, Silberstein and Captain
Baxley look like a mighty •good
scoring combination and should
make a lot of trouble for opposing teams this year.

TELLS OF SHIP CONSTRUCTION
Aldred Lecturer Describes Modern Steel
Freight Ships Designed for TransAtlantic Trade—Discussses Cost
of Building and Operating.

"The Modern Steel Freight
Ship" was the subject of the
Aldred lecture of April 2 delivered by Mr. D. D. Thomas, chief
engineer of the Baltimore Dry
Docks and Shipbuilding Company.
The size of the ships now being
built for the trans-Atlantic trade,
Mr. Thomas stated, is a matter
of wide discussion, as well as of
great disagreement. Full information must be given the builder
by the owners, regarding the uses
for which the vessels are intended. Consideration must be
given to the types of cargohandling machinery, and likewise
to the running apparatus. The
boilers, engines, and their auxiliaries must be designed to meet
operating conditions. Where oil
is obtainable for fuel, water-tube
boilers are best for coal, Scotch
boilers are most widely used.
The cost of building and operating ships depends upon the materials and speed of construction,
upon the fuel used in running,
the wages of the crew, and the
economy of operation and possibilities of reduction of the engineroom force. Large ships cost less
in proportion than smaller ones,
but their size is limited by the
ports and by weather conditions
at sea. In the future most of the
freight ships will be over 1,800
tons dead weight capacity.
The construction of one of the
new fabricated steel ships was
next outlined. After the specifications have been drawn up, and
the contract has been given, the
mid-ship section and profile plans
are made, using data from previous ships. The distribution of
weights is effected by dividing
the ship into "weight groups."
The lines are then designed. Detail plans are made in the drafting room in their logical order
as needed. A model is made from
the lines determined, to a small
scale, and the plates are laid out
on its surfaces. The task of laying out the full-size molds and
;templates is then accomplished in
the mold loft, by a system of perpendicular offsets. It must be remembered that certain parts of
the ships have many intricate
systems of curvature, and much
care must be taken if all of the
sections are to fit together neatly.
The fabrication consists of preparing the members for assembly.
Identification of all of the parts
is an important detail. The process of fabrication has advanced
so much in the last few years
that now 80 per cent. of the material of the ship may be prepared
away from the ship, speeding up
the work immeasurably.

The subject for the 1919 contest
for the medal offered by the Baron
Coubertin for the best oral discussion of modern French politics
or literature will be: "The Future of France as Influenced by
a League of Nations."
Suggested sub-topics:
(a) The future of France in a
Europe of alliances and balances
of Power.
(b) The burden of reconstruction and the national defense.
(c) France and sea power.
(d) What France deserves from
her allies.
Preliminary trials to select
three or four speakers will be held
April 9, at 1 o'clock, in Room 112.
Speeches of four minutes will be
adequate. The final contest will
probably be held May 9. In that
contest the speeches will be ten
minutes in length.
The Tocqueville contest is open
to all undergraduates, and it is
to be hoped that a large number
of men will try out. It is the
most significant prize that a collegiate student can win.

The Opening Game.

Since the Alumni boasted practically, the same galaxy of stars
as the year previous, the 'Varsity
victory has a most welcome significance. We may look next Saturday for complete revenge for
the 12 to 0 defeat handed us
by Navy last April. It is to
be regretted that Saturday's
weather spoiled the baseball
team's chances for such vengeance, but that score can be settled a few weeks hence.
We might have expected that
such an auspicious opening of
the season at Homewood would
have infused irrepressible pep
into the stands. The yells, however, were of the very poorest
order; not only were they lacking in technique, but in volume
and enthusiasm. Practice can
and must be held, preferably at
a mass meeting, or after some of
the weekly lectures. The yells
should, by all means, have been
rehearsed at the fully-attended
meeting last Thursday in the C.
E. hall, just two days before the
Alumni game.
A feature of the game which
well deserves notice was the presence at one of the goals of a service flag with three gold stars.
The Lacrosse Association has
drawn up a set of resolutions
providing for a service flag with
stars in honor of the memory of
three former Hopkins lacrosse
players who made the supreme
sacrifice.
This simple memorial on the
field on which these three brave
spirits gave their best for Hopkins, is especially appropriate.

RHODES SCHOLARSHIPS RESUMED
Former Qualifying Examination to Be
Discontinued—Candidates Need Only
Make Formal Application, Endorsed by the Authorities

As recently announced, appointments to Rhodes scholarships in
the United States, which were
postponed for the duration of the
war, will be resumed in October,
1919. The scholarships which
were not awarded during the war
will be allotted in addition to the
current ones during the next three
years.
In his will, Cecil Rhodes provided that two scholarships be constantly at Oxford from each State
in the Union. During the three
years of the Oxford course, the
scholar stays at Oxford and receives the sum of three hundred
pounds a year, out of which he
pays his tuition, fees and expenses,
exactly as . any other student.
There are no restrictions as to
the subjects which he is to study.
Rhodes scholars may choose any
of the various Oxford Honor
Schools, or may work for the Oxford research degrees. Candidates
must be unmarried, between the
ages of nineteen and twenty-five
and must have completed at least
their second year in college. Candidates may try for the appointment either from the State 'in
which they reside or from that
in which. they have received the
major part of their education.
The qualifying examination
which has been required of all
candidates in the past is now to
be abandoned, and to try for the
appointment it will only be necessary for candidates to make formal application, endorsed by the
authorities of their college or university. The selection will be made
in the future, as in the past, on
the basis of a man's record in
school and college, according to
the four points outlined in the
Rhodes will: (1) scholarship, (2)
character, (3) interest in outdoor
sports, and (4) interest in one's
fellows and instincts for leadership.
The selection of scholars will
be made by committees constituted for that purpose in each State.
A list of the names of the men to
whom application should be made
and the formal application blanks
will be published in June.

IN GERMAN PRISON CAMP
(Continued from fiage 1)
IS

see boys brought to the hospitals
in so exhausted a condition that
they expired soon after they were
brought in. Captain Maxson experienced no brutality. He was
soon sent back to the prison camp
and always treated as an American officer. The American Red
Cross and the Y. M. C. A. performed wonderful service at the
German prison camps, where university extension work was carried on. Captain Maxson paid a
great tribute to the American
privates. "The American private
in Germany was the finest soldier I have ever seen," he said.
"He so conducted himself that he
won the respect of his enemies

at once."
The German student-body from
the German universities were at
all times out of harmony with
Germany. They saw nothing but
disaster whether win or lose. The
one-time prisoner saw a demonstration of the German revolution. He said the future of Germany looked very uncertain. She
has the spirit to win, but whether
she will or not depends on
whether she will be .able to overcome the Bolshevik tendency.
Captain Maxson hopes that the
college men of America will help
to keep American spirit on as
firm a basis of true social democracy as it was in 1913, through
the period of discontent now facing the world. America has
shown the world that her past is
a guarantee of the future. Un-

less we refuse to permit the
Bolshevik tendencies, our future,
he says, will be as black as Germany's.

Get-together Meetings for Student Body.
To the Eaitor of THE NEWS-LETTER:

Sir:—The Johns Hopkins University is so well known that an
outsider naturally expects to find
Within the student body a spirit
of University pride and unity
equal to the reputation. This
Spirit is noticeable for its absence rather than for its presence. Entering Hopkins from a
less well known college, I have
been greatly disappointed, not in
the faculty or grade of scholarship, but in the lack of organization in the undergraduate body.
One can scarcely realize that
there is no time at which all the
classes come together for an address by the president, dean, or
faculty of the University. A
general announcement cannot be
made, nor can an important matter be urged except through_ a
specially printed card, the MowsLETTER, or the use of the Open
Forum on Thursday through the
courtesy of the Y. M. C. A. cabinet. The greatest spirit, enthusiasm, and feeling of unity is
found where get-together meetings are held, whether at the
training table, smokers in the
dorms, discussion groups, or in
the fraternities. Such a meeting
in this University body would be
no exception.
Through the chapel the majority of the colleges in this country
meet this need. Such a meeting
Of students for a short time offers a chance for a talk by the
officers of the University as well
as student announcements of all
activities. The new athletic program can get its strength from
this source, the Hopkins spirit its
life.
0. W. U.

subscribe to the Hullabaloo is
their duty both to the University
and themselves that I am writing
this letter.
It should be emphasized that
this year's Uullabaloo, as never
before, will represent every class
equally. Every student activity
from freshman to senior will receive equal attention. Furthermore this year's staff is no longer
hampered by war conditions, and
every effort will be made to make
this book a worthy memorial to
the great work which Hopkins
has done in the past war. That
this effort will be a success is
undoubted. More and better material, more pictures and better
drawings have been received than
ever before. Even without further additions this year's Hullabaloo would be the best ever published, and with every additional
dollar more can be added to it.
It is needless I think to point
out that, in addition to these
facts, it is through the Hullabaloo
only that we can obtain a perfect
and lasting record of the activities of our class during its freshman year.
A FRESHMAN.

PHI BETA KAPPAS TO BE
ELECTED APRIL 15th.

The annual meeting of the PhiBeta Kappa Society will be held
on Tuesday, April 15. At this
meeting a lucky half-dozen members of the Class of 1919 will be
elected to the society on the basis
of their scholarship during the
past four years. For the next few
months wrist watches will be discarded, so that the keys may
adorn the watch chain on the
vest. The banquet will be held
on Saturday night, April 26, and
although the arrangements have
not been completed, it is known
that Dr. Joseph Ames will be one
of the speakers.

A group of forty-seven seniors
gathered at the Hotel Emerson
on March 31, and, figuratively
speaking, took the roof off the
house; for this was the prerogative of the senior banquet. After
keeping the class waiting for
about an hour—perhaps for the
purpose of putting all edge on the
appetites — the committee announced dinner.
Mr. Williams, commonly known
as "Tiff," was the toastmaster,
and his scintillating wit was
evinced in the veritable barrage
of stories which he "got away
with." He first introduced President Chisholm, who spoke about
"The Class." A note of sadness
was drawn into this speech when
President Chisholm remarked that
this would probably be the last
time the class would meet "on
common ground." The gloom, however, speedily disappeared after
Mr. Schmidt's opening sentence,
for he refused "to get off any serious stuff." He launched a witty
tirade against the academic men,
large numbers of whom seem to
have gotten an average of ten or
close to it. Mr. Schmidt attributes this to the fact that the academic courses are easier than
those given in the Engineering Department.
At this point, the toastmaster
announced that President Goodnow, who was to have been the
guest of honor, was prevented
from attending the banquet by illhealth, and he had requested the
toastmaster to convey his regrets
to the class. Mr. Harris Kirk
then spoke on "Reminiscences of
Our Freshman Banquet," and told
of the halcyon days when sophomores were served with the food
for the amusement of the "freshies." "Tommy" was scheduled to
speak on "The Hullabaloo," but
as he is the editor of that book,
and felt that he could not with
delicacy give it its due measure
of praise, he told some side-splitting—that's what he termed them
—negro stories instead. But the
hit of the evening was made by
heavy John Stanley, who chanted
a piece entitled "Damn 9111Pir
Eyes," which brought sponta
-1
applause from every member
the class.
Dr. Hulburt,the honorary president of the class, was suffering
from a very severe cold and could
not be present. The set speeches
were concluded by Mr. L. W. Simon, who demonstrated how interesting a discourse can be delivered on "Nothing in Particular."
"Tiff" found that he had several
pretty good stories which, owing
to the absence of Dr. Goodnow
and Dr. Hulburt, he had not told.
